repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Primary Education and Teacher
            Decelopment and Education Sector Adjustment Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the projects are as
            follows: The outcome of the Primary Education and Teacher
            Development Project is moderately satisfactory, while the
            outcome for the Education Sector Adjustment Credit Project
            is satisfactory; for both, project sustainability is likely,
            institutional development impact is substantial, and Bank
            and Borrower performances are satisfactory overall.  Theses
            were the lessons learned concerning Bank support to
            expansion of primary education: 1) Very rapid expansion of
            enrollments, even with appropriate increase in funding, is
            liable to disrupt efforts to improve the efficiency and
            effectiveness of systems for delivering inputs to schools
            and for monitoring the quality of learning processes and
            outputs. Thorough diagnosis is needed of the weaknesses in
            these systems and of the time. needed to rectify them, to
            determine absorptive capacity. Attention should be given to
            prioritization and sequencing, to avoid overloading the
            reform agenda.  2) To protect the quality of education while
            expanding the capacity of the system, project design should
            be based on analysis of existing strengths and weaknesses at
            the school and classroom levels, providing a baseline for
            monitoring relevant indicators.  3) "Big bang"
            expansion of primary enrollments has long-term downstream
            fiscal implications beyond just the primary sub-sector.
            Uganda is confronting the need to increase capital and
            recurrent funding to post-primary education, now that pupils
            in the universal primary education (UPE) bulge are
            completing the primary cycle. Growth in the number of
            teachers has become a major issue for the public service
            payroll as a whole and is inhibiting pay reform. Lessons
            concerning use of adjustment lending through a sector-wide
            approach (SWAP) for education include the following: 1) The
            combination of budget support and investment lending can be
            an effective form of Bank support to expand primary
            education in countries with commitment to good policies but
            weak capacity to implement them. The two projects were
            mutually supportive. 2) Given strong ministry leadership, a
            SWAP can be quickly established, with benefits for the
            coherence of sector strategy, the quality and national
            ownership of sector policies, and transparency of sector
            planning and budget processes, but it presents new issues
            for aid management.  3) Maintaining donor and public
            confidence depends on special measures for fiduciary
            assurance which can be difficult to sustain.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Primary Education and Teacher
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, though with only modest institutional
            impacts. Lessons of general application indicate that the
            prolonged use of donor-financed consultants, or long-term
            technical assistants, tend to endanger capacity building,
            lowering the likelihood of sustainability. It is thus
            stipulated that the use of a Project Implementation Unit
            structure - whether or not its staff are civil servants -
            does prevent the accumulated experience of being transferred
            to other line units. And, had the Teacher Development and
            Management System, as well as the instructional materials
            component incorporated periodic evaluations, a better
            targeted instructional quality would have been achieved,
            namely, the curriculum reform, examination, and other
            programs. Lessons of sector application vary, from the
            possibility to attain universal primary education by
            streamlining complex programs, to the need to maintain a
            focus on desired outcomes, critical for increased
            educational quality. Additionally, centralized materials
            procurement is perceived as unpractical in Uganda, given
            inadequacies in transportation, and management systems.
            Other issues address the importance to strike a balance
            between quantitative and qualitative indicators to guide
            policy matters; to improve linkages among training, teacher
            practices, and learning achievement; of shared ownership;
            and, of assessment systems to help teachers in the daily
            particulars of student learning.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Primary Education and Teacher
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the project are to
            assist the government by reforming the pattern of resource
            mobilization and resource allocation in the sector, and by
            financing specific investment expenditures.  Primary school
            teaching and management will be improved through the
            development of an integrated support system linking primary
            teacher colleges to a surrounding network of primary schools
            to provide field-based upgrading and continuous in-service
            training for school managers and instructional staff and the
            rehabilitation and construction of primary school and
            related teacher training facilities; the provision of
            learning resources, particularly textbooks and supplementary
            reading materials; and the revitalization of the private
            sector capacity to produce such learning resources.
            Strategic planning, policy analysis, management and
            implementation functions will be enhanced by strengthening
            the Ministry of Education and Sports Planning Unit and
            conducting special policy studies in the areas of secondary
            education, book policy development and the national
            assessment of educational performance; upgrading management
            and information systems, particularly in the areas of
            personnel, accounting and auditing; reforming the curriculum
            and examinations; and expanding and decentralizing
            implementation capacity.
